data.title: WI:John of Eltham survives and marries Joan of Penthièvre
data.meta_description: In December 1335, Edward III started negociations with Brittany so his brother John would marry Joan, Countess of Penthièvre (1319-1384). It came to nothing...
data.text:
In December 1335, Edward III started negociations with Brittany so his brother John would marry Joan, Countess of Penthièvre (1319-1384). It came to nothing in OTL and Joan married Charles of Blois, Philip VI's nephew.

When the War of the Breton Succession started in 1341, Philip supported Joan and her husband, and Edward supported Joan's half-uncle John of Montfort.

If John of Eltham marries Joan and survives, how could it affect history?

For starters you'll have France supporting Montfort and England supporting Joan/Eltham.

And a much more logical choice it will be, since France supported the female claimant and England did the male claimant OTL!

I think John of Eltham could be more successful than Charles of Blois, not getting captured at La Roche-Derrien in 1347.

And a much more logical choice it will be, since France supported the female claimant and England did the male claimant OTL!

I think John of Eltham could be more successful than Charles of Blois, not getting captured at La Roche-Derrien in 1347.

Agreed there and with his military experience already he might get some positive results

Agreed there and with his military experience already he might get some positive results

An Eltham/Montfort duel would be more balanced than Blois/Montfort.

Also, Edward III supported Montfort OTL because Breton support was needed in his war against France and Philip was already supporting Joan and Blois. But with Joan married to Eltham, Edward would at once push for them to be acknowledged as Duke and Duchess.

An Eltham/Montfort duel would be more balanced than Blois/Montfort.

Also, Edward III supported Montfort OTL because Breton support was needed in his war against France and Philip was already supporting Joan and Blois. But with Joan married to Eltham, Edward would at once push for them to be acknowledged as Duke and Duchess.

Agreed and their claim would be superior

Agreed and their claim would be superior

Very true. And Brittany had already had four duchesses!

Am I wrong to think France is the only country that barred women from the succession?

Very true. And Brittany had already had four duchesses!

Am I wrong to think France is the only country that barred women from the succession?

Austria and Prussia also aha

An idea of family tree for Joan and John:

Joan of Penthièvre, Duchess of Brittany (1319-1384) m. John of Eltham, Earl of Cornwall (1316-1379)

Marie of Brittany (b.1337)

John IV, Duke of Brittany (b.1339) [1]

Stillborn son (1340)

Edward, Count of Penthièvre (b.1345)

Joan of Brittany (b.1345)

Guy of Brittany (b.1346)

Arthur of Brittany (b.1350)

Constance of Brittany (1351)

[1] Or John V if John of Montfort is considered a Duke during the War of the Breton Succession
